newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile's Paipote copper smelter in wage talks.
newsitem.headline: Chile's Paipote copper smelter in wage talks.

text.p: Chile's state-owned Paipote copper smelter has started collective wage negotiations with workers to renew the plant's labor contract which expires at the end of the month, said a union leader.
"We are in the second week of talks and expect the company to make its first offer towards the end of the week," Luis Araya, acting president of the smelter's only union, told Reuters.
The plant's owners Empresa Nacional de Mineria (Enami) are offering a five year deal to replace the current two-year contract, said Araya.
Paipote is Chile's smallest copper smelter with production of 68,000 tonnes of copper anodes a year.
Wage talks are also due to start in January at Enami's much larger Ventanas smelter and refinery which produces 240,000 tonnes of copper a year.
Workers at Ventanas went on strike for 10 days two years ago when wage negotiations broke down.
Chile's all-important copper industry has suffered a rash of strikes this year with walkouts at three pits including state copper company Codelco's Chuquicamata and Salvador mines.
